Plot Summary:
The story unfolds in the South American jungle, where Barney Chavez (Raymond Burr), the overseer of a plantation, kills his employer in a fit of rage. Hoping to cover up the crime, he marries his bossâ€™s widow, the beautiful Dina Van Gelder (Barbara Payton). However, his guilt and paranoia grow after a local witch curses him, causing him to believe he is transforming into a jungle beast. The police commissioner, Taro (Lon Chaney Jr.), investigates the mysterious death and the subsequent reports of a monstrous creature roaming the jungle. As paranoia, superstition, and guilt consume Barney, his descent into madness becomes inevitable, blurring the line between man and beast.

While Bride of the Gorilla was produced on a modest budget, it remains significant for its combination of horror and psychological thriller elements. Curt Siodmak, celebrated for his horror screenwriting, used this film to explore themes of guilt, superstition, and transformation. The film is a prime example of how low-budget horror films of the 1950s blended exoticism, supernatural elements, and moral cautionary tales to appeal to audiences in postwar America and abroad.

metadata.Plot: Deep in the South American jungle plantation manager Barney Chavez (Raymond Burr) kills his elderly employer in order to get to his beautiful wife (Barbara Payton). However, an old native witch witnesses the crime and puts a curse on Barney, who soon after finds himself turning nightly into a rampaging gorilla. But is his transformation real or is it all in his head?
